subject: Re: One test for all implementors of an interface
msgSnippet: Not sure I follow.  Are you suggesting to pass the class under test as a parameter to a factory via the test constructor?  From what I ve seen, parameterized
messageBody:
Not sure I follow. Are you suggesting to pass the class under test as
a parameter to a factory via the test constructor? From what I've
seen, parameterized tests seem aimed in a very different direction.
Could you point us to discussion or examples of this usage?

I can see some potential convenience for abstract classes and
interfaces representing the primary type of each implementation,
provided the family resemblance manifests itself in a common
constructor signature. For "mixin" interfaces, uniformity of
constructors seems less likely. The specter of type-switching logic
creeping into the factory seems likely to undermine not only
convenience but cleanliness. As I said, maybe elaboration or examples
from someone more experienced in this area than I am would help.

Thanks,
Lance

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>
> 2009/1/15 J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...>:
> > On 2008-12-14, at 14:54 , Ilja Preu√ü wrote:
> >> http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?AbstractTest
> >>
> > I'm really surprised it took so long for someone to refer to Abstract
> > Test Cases or Contract Tests.
>
> Well, these days it's *much* more convenient to use JUnit 4's
> parameterised tests.
>
> --Nat
>
